Situation1: Laundry piles up, but someone eventually finds time to fold it.
Expectation2: Wash and condition clients' hair before cutting or styling
Situation2: The hair is a bit sweaty after a gym session and looks greasy.
Story: I stare at the mountain of laundry on the couch, shirts and socks tumbling over each other, a silent reminder of my promise to share the chores with my husband. He’s been picking up the slack all week, and I know he’s expecting me to finally tackle the folding tonight. But my phone buzzes—a last-minute client, desperate for a wash and cut before her big interview tomorrow. I glance at the clock. If I leave now, I can just make it to the salon in time. My mind races: the client’s hair will need extra care after her gym session, and she’s counting on me to make her look her best. But the laundry sits there, accusing, and I can almost hear my husband’s tired sigh when he sees it untouched again. My chest tightens as I weigh the expectations—am I a reliable partner at home, or a dedicated professional at work? I stand frozen, keys in one hand, a crumpled t-shirt in the other, torn between the two worlds that both need me right now.
